curriculumAlignment.outcomeDescription: Sedimentary, igneous and metamorphic rocks contain minerals and are formed by processes that occur within Earth over a variety of timescales
curriculumAlignment.v9ContentDescriptor: Classify rocks as sedimentary, igneous or metamorphic based on their observable properties and how they are formed; identify that all rocks are composed of one or more minerals
elaborations: Representing the stages in the formation of igneous, metamorphic and sedimentary rocks, including indications of timescales involved
Identifying a range of common rock types using a key based on observable physical and chemical properties
Recognising that rocks are a collection of different minerals
Considering the role of forces and energy in the formation of different types of rocks and minerals
Recognising that some rocks and minerals, such as ores, provide valuable resources

keyConcepts.name: Three rock types
keyConcepts.description: Rocks are classified into three main types based on formation: igneous (from cooled magma/lava), sedimentary (from compressed sediments), metamorphic (from heat/pressure transformation)

keyConcepts.name: Igneous rock formation
keyConcepts.description: Igneous rocks form when molten rock (magma/lava) cools and solidifies. Intrusive rocks cool slowly underground (large crystals), extrusive rocks cool quickly on surface (small crystals)

keyConcepts.name: Sedimentary rock formation
keyConcepts.description: Sedimentary rocks form when sediments (weathered rock particles, shells, organic matter) are deposited, buried, compacted, and cemented over time

keyConcepts.name: Metamorphic rock formation
keyConcepts.description: Metamorphic rocks form when existing rocks are transformed by extreme heat and/or pressure without melting (recrystallization)

keyConcepts.name: Minerals vs rocks
keyConcepts.description: Minerals are naturally occurring inorganic solids with a definite chemical composition and crystalline structure. Rocks are aggregates of one or more minerals

keyConcepts.name: Rock cycle
keyConcepts.description: The continuous process of rock formation, breakdown, and reformation through geological processes (weathering, erosion, deposition, burial, metamorphism, melting, cooling)

keyConcepts.name: Geological timescales
keyConcepts.description: Rock formation processes occur over vastly different timescales - from hours (volcanic eruptions) to millions of years (mountain formation)

keyConcepts.name: Tectonic forces and energy
keyConcepts.description: Earth's internal heat and plate tectonics provide the energy and forces that drive rock formation processes (magma generation, mountain building, burial)

keyConcepts.name: Mineral identification properties
keyConcepts.description: Minerals are identified by physical properties: hardness (Mohs scale), streak, luster, cleavage/fracture, color, crystal shape

keyConcepts.name: Rock and mineral resources
keyConcepts.description: Rocks and minerals as valuable resources: ores (metal sources), building materials, fossil fuels, and their extraction/sustainability considerations

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Rocks and minerals are the same thing
commonMisconceptions.correction: Minerals are pure substances with a specific chemical composition and crystal structure (e.g., quartz, feldspar). Rocks are made of one or more minerals combined together (e.g., granite contains quartz, feldspar, and mica)

commonMisconceptions.misconception: The rock cycle follows one predetermined order
commonMisconceptions.correction: Any rock type can transform into any other type directly - the cycle has multiple pathways. Sedimentary can melt directly to become igneous without being metamorphic first
Metamorphic rocks form without melting - they stay solid throughout the transformation. Only if temperature exceeds the melting point does the rock become magma (then igneous when it cools)

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Geological processes only happen over millions of years
commonMisconceptions.correction: Some processes are very fast (volcanic eruption in hours, obsidian cooling in minutes) while others take millions of years (mountain formation, sedimentary rock layers)

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Earth's surface is constant and unchanging
commonMisconceptions.correction: Earth's surface is constantly being reshaped by geological processes including weathering, erosion, volcanic activity, and plate tectonics

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Soil is the precursor of rocks (soil changes to clay to rock)
commonMisconceptions.correction: Soil forms FROM weathered rocks, not the other way around. Soil is the product of rock breakdown, not the starting material for rock formation

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Minerals form separately, then come together to form rocks
commonMisconceptions.correction: Minerals typically crystallize together as the rock forms - from cooling magma, from precipitation, or during recrystallization. They don't join pre-formed
Size doesn't determine if something is a rock. A small piece of granite is still a rock, not a different material. 'Stone' is just an informal term

commonMisconceptions.misconception: All metals are hard (high hardness on Mohs scale)
commonMisconceptions.correction: Many metals are quite soft - gold can be scratched with a fingernail (hardness 2.5), lead is even softer. Diamond is the hardest material, not a metal
The mantle is mostly solid rock that flows very slowly over geological time (like thick honey). Only localized pockets melt to form magma. The outer core is liquid, not the mantle

realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: How did a giant rock 348 meters tall form in the middle of a flat desert? And why is it red?
realWorldPhenomena.australianRelevance: Australia's most famous rock formation, UNESCO World Heritage site, cultural significance to Anangu people

realWorldPhenomena.phenomenon: Pilbara ancient rocks (4 billion years old)
realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: Why does Western Australia have some of the oldest rocks on Earth, and what can they tell us about early Earth?
realWorldPhenomena.australianRelevance: Pilbara contains rocks nearly as old as Earth itself; Jack Hills zircons date to 4.4 billion years

realWorldPhenomena.phenomenon: Victorian gold rush nuggets in quartz veins
realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: Why is gold found in white quartz rocks, and why were so many massive nuggets found in Victoria?
realWorldPhenomena.australianRelevance: Victoria's gold rush shaped Australian history; many world's largest nuggets found here; orogenic gold deposits

realWorldPhenomena.phenomenon: Pilbara iron ore banded iron formations
realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: How did Australia end up with the world's largest iron ore deposits, and what do the colored bands tell us about ancient Earth?
realWorldPhenomena.australianRelevance: 35% of Australia's exports; banded iron formations are over 2 billion years old; evidence of early oxygen atmosphere

realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: How did flat layers of sandstone become towering cliffs with a hazy blue appearance?
realWorldPhenomena.australianRelevance: World Heritage Area near Sydney; shows dramatic weathering and erosion; eucalyptus oil creates blue haze

realWorldPhenomena.phenomenon: Volcanic islands of Lord Howe Island
realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: Why is this island shaped like a crescent, and what happened to the rest of the volcano?
realWorldPhenomena.australianRelevance: World's most southerly coral reef; remnant of 7-million-year-old volcano; basalt rocks clearly visible

realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: Why does Australia produce 95% of the world's opals, and why do people live underground in Coober Pedy?
realWorldPhenomena.australianRelevance: 'Opal capital of the world'; unique mineral formation in sedimentary rock; underground homes due to extreme heat

realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: How did three valuable metals end up concentrated together in the same location?
realWorldPhenomena.australianRelevance: One of Australia's most productive mining regions; polymetallic ore deposits; Queensland economy

realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: Why do these granite boulders look like they're balancing on top of each other?
realWorldPhenomena.australianRelevance: Victoria's most famous national park; dramatic granite landscape; evidence of spheroidal weathering

realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: The Great Barrier Reef is made of rock, not just coral. How do living creatures create stone?
realWorldPhenomena.australianRelevance: World's largest reef system; biogenic limestone; connection between living organisms and rock formation

scaffoldingSequence.name: Rock Types Foundation
scaffoldingSequence.focus: Identifying and distinguishing the three rock types by their formation and observable properties

scaffoldingSequence.name: Minerals and Properties
scaffoldingSequence.focus: Understanding minerals as rock building blocks, mineral identification properties, rocks vs minerals distinction

scaffoldingSequence.name: Processes and Connections
scaffoldingSequence.focus: Rock cycle pathways, transformation processes, challenging misconceptions about formation

scaffoldingSequence.name: Deep Earth and Applications
scaffoldingSequence.focus: Tectonic forces, energy sources, resources, complex multi-step transformations

cognitiveLoadNotes: Start with observable rock samples before introducing formation processes - concrete before abstract
Use visual rock cycle diagrams that show multiple pathways, not just one circular sequence
Introduce one rock type fully before comparing to others - avoid simultaneous introduction
Connect geological timescales to familiar references (human lifetime, recorded history, dinosaurs)
Use hands-on mineral testing before introducing Mohs scale numbers
engagementStrategies: Start with local Australian geology examples students might have visited (Uluru, Blue Mountains)
Use prediction activities: 'Will this rock scratch glass?' before testing
Show before/after photos of geological changes (volcanic eruptions, landslides)
Connect to construction materials around school - identify rocks in buildings
Use gold/gem mining stories to hook interest in mineral identification
motivationFactors: Connect to Australian mining industry and economy (iron ore, gold, opals)
Relate to adventure activities (rock climbing, caving, beach exploration)
Link to careers (geologist, mining engineer, jeweler, stonemason)
Connect to Aboriginal cultural significance of rock formations
Relate to natural disasters (volcanic eruptions, landslides) for relevance
desirableDifficulties: Mix rock type identification questions rather than grouping by type
Include 'trick' questions about rock cycle pathways to challenge predetermined order misconception
Vary timescales in questions (fast vs slow processes) to prevent anchoring
Require identification AND explanation of formation process together
Include Australian examples mixed with international for transfer
testingEffectOpportunities: Mineral identification quizzes using property descriptions
Rock cycle pathway prediction before revealing

questionDesignGuidelines.mcqDistractorStrategy: Use documented misconceptions as distractors: rock/mineral confusion (m1), predetermined cycle order (m2), metamorphic melting (m3), timescale misconceptions (m4)
questionDesignGuidelines.shortAnswerFocus: Require process explanations for transformations; ask students to connect observations to formation processes
questionDesignGuidelines.diagramQuestions: At least 35% of questions should involve rock cycle diagrams, rock sample images, or mineral property testing scenarios
questionDesignGuidelines.calculationOpportunities: Limited - focus on qualitative. Could include Mohs scale relative comparisons
questionDesignGuidelines.realWorldApplication: At least 50% should reference Australian geological features or mining industry
questionDesignGuidelines.misconceptionTargeting: Each phase should address 2-3 key misconceptions with questions designed to reveal and correct them

supportStrategies: Use color-coded graphic organizers for three rock types
Offer sentence starters: 'This rock is igneous because...'
Provide physical rock samples for tactile learners
Use simplified rock cycle diagrams with clear arrows
extensionOpportunities: Investigate radiometric dating methods for rocks
Explore Australian geological history in depth
Study plate tectonics and its role in rock formation
Research careers in geology and mining
